title: Petri Level Curing Station (PDMS) for LittleRP

description.text:
Use this station to keep your petri dishes level and dust free while the PDMS coating cures. Bonus it kinda looks like a Yurt.

EDIT: It works fine, I've made several petris now and they all seem very level. Just be careful not to rotate the base once you level it, as thesurface it is resting on may not be level. If someone finds an inexpensive two axis level to include in the design, please let me know.

Tap the three holes in the bottom with an M5 tap, then screw in a M5x30 screw into each hole. I included a spring to keep the tension on the screw, but I don't think that is required. Use a bubble level to make sure that the base is level, using the screws to adjust the balance. Once you have placed the petri with the uncured PDMS on the platform, cover with the round shaped lid. It should work, I'm testing it with my first petri. One modification would be a flat top, I just thought the dome makes it look nice and give it some room for air to circulate. If I use a flat top it should be possible to stack levels, taking advantage of the leveling legs for multiple petri dishes.

EDIT: I have made several petris and all of them came out very well, better than if I had just let them cure on the table.

remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
My first attempt of creating a 3D printer. It is for my A-Level Product Design and loosely based on the MendalMax - but all my own design. The only two parts that are a near exact copy of other parts are the direct drive extruder by raldrich and droftart's parametic pulleys. I have simply converted the extruder to use a NEMA 14 stepper rather than the geared motor. The idea was to make a simple to build printer using as few nuts and bolts as possible and maximum printed parts. Also I wanted to have a double extrusion system as well. Build volume is 200x200x170mm on one extruder or about 200x150x170 with both extruders I have no guarantees that this will even work - but I plan to eventually build it. I would welcome any constructive comments to improve it. Also any suggestions for a better name would be great ;) Once I start to order parts I will update a BoM on here. I have tried to keep it so that all the parts are the same throughout the printer (same linear bearings, bearings, 8mm rod to all axis' etc) to reduce the number of different parts to order. Attached is the SketchUp file of the complete fabricator - again I will update with STL's of parts as I start to build. Update 25/07/2013
Final parts ordered for the heated bed and hotend. Will be waiting about 4 weeks for the hotend to turn up (going for an E3D one). Hopefully will have it all operating soon. Update 10/07/2013
Project files are now available on GitHub: https://github.com/smartroad/DSF. I'll be maintaining on there while building then update again here any final changes. Update 23/06/2013
While I wait for payday so I can buy the steppers and electronics I have started to create the build manual. It isn't complete but should give a feel for the style I want to go for. Any suggestions gratefully received! Update 16/06/2013
Finally finished the design and have printed, and built, all of the printer. Currently updating this page with all the new STLs and SketchUP file. Now I have to wait until I can afford to buy the steppers, electronics, power supply and hotends! STLs have now been uploaded. Update 12/06/2013
Continued building the machine now have the Y and Z axis installed. Did make a small error of forgetting to put the bearings on the rod before I installed them! I am hoping by the end of the week that I shall have all the parts printed and ready to go. I will then be waiting on steppers, electronics and the hotend. Update 31/05/2013
Changed from using the MXL pulley gear from RepRapPro to droftart's parametric T5 one. Update 29/05/2013
Started build. Pictures uploaded of frame progress. Update 21/05/2013
Started ordering so here is the link to the BoM Update 18/05/2013
Added the STLs. The carriage is still not complete as I have yet to decide on a hotend etc. Also haven't added the extruder yet - although the current design can be pulled from the SketchUp file.

description.text: this is a self adjusting pond overflow or surface skimmer that i made for my koi pond. you also need to get 4" PVC pipe as a shaft so the overflow only move up and down

printed using 100% infill because i you want it to last. ABS or PLA is fine, scale it up 5 times or until the diameter is 15 cm. after printing fill the outer cavity with some foam, i use polyfoam strips but any foam will do fill and keep testing to match with the system your using to suck the water surface. i'm using some of my pond gravity filtration system to do the suction so i only need to set the top surface about 1/4 of an inch above the water line.

A four-tentacled stand for an iPhone 6 Plus. I printed it on a See Me CNC Orion with MatterControl and the default slicer (the other two slicers didn't deal well with the suckers and base). This maxed out the print area of my machine.

This is based on an old Blender rigging demo of a tentacle (http://mirror.cs.umn.edu/blender.org/demo/test/Octopus.blend) duplicated 4 times and arranged around an iPhone 6-Plus model. Exported to STL, sliced in MatterControl and Slic3r.

UPDATE: Reworked to reorient the tentacles and flatten the base. Also added some fill on the base for the phone to sit on after a careless placement sent the stand flying. Much more stable this way. New file is TentacleStand.base.stl sliced with MatterControl's build in slicer. There does appear to be a void where the tentacles meet and my limited blender skills haven't been able to get rid of. The blend is up as well if anyone wants to fix it.
A cap designed to fit over the end of a vacuum cleaner hose. (Will also fit over the multi-hose adapters I created).
~32mm diameter size
The Sunhokey Prusa i3 X axis has quite some play in it. This thing is an upgrade to the X axis base plate and uses four LM8UU bearings greatly increasing the stability.

For Sunhokey acrylic Prusa i3.

I printed this using a 0.4mm nozzle with a 0.2mm layer height and 50% infill with Slic3r. It has made an amazing difference to the output quality of my printed models. Use the existing hot end acrylic plate, nut, and screw. Simply press in 4 x LM8UU bearings and put on your X axis rods. The spacing is 45mm between rods.

remixed_from.author: bstott
remixed_from.title: Crazyflie Bumper Cage with Battery Holder

description.text:
Protect your Crazyflie and household with this V2 prop bumper shield. This accessory will also make it simple and quick to swap out batteries to extend your flying time.  
Total weight is ~5.4 grams.  
Can be made lighter if you print only 1.02mm of thickness.  
Edit - May 20, 2013 ---- > Flies Great!

Print

  • Two of the Bumper Shields.

  • Cement or glue the two bumper shields to make an assembly to match the above picture.
  • Install on Crazyflie with small pieces of doubleback tape.
    • Print

  • One each of the two Bumper Cage files.

  • Cement the two halves together. Look to the picture for reference. The central circular hubs overlap to make it easy to glue and align the two halves.
  • Once each file is printed and the halves are glued together then slip the two resulting parts together at the central hub.
    • Clip the assembled Cage onto the Shield to best fit and orientation for the battery. Use small drops of glue where the Cage touches the Shield to hold the Cage into position. Do Not Glue to the Crazyflie. Install the battery. You may still need a small amount of doubleback tape underneath the battery but, much less and easier to remove than original. The down pointing pillar on the central hub of the Cage is to help hold the battery in position. I use a folded piece of hobby foam sheet between the pillar and battery to add pressure onto the battery.

author: bobbaggins

description.text:
See the original for full description. This version includes a couple of minor fixes and updates for openscad 2015. Modifications:

  • For the sake of the customizer I've set the tooth size to 2*pi mm. This makes the pitch radius equal to the number of gears. If you want different gear teeth sizes you can either download and edit the openscad file or scale the gear in your printer software.
  • Added some different hole types including D, and hex for coupling to D-shafts and Hex bolts.
  • Adopted a bug fix
  • Users can now enter the helix angle rather than the degrees of twist.
  • Fixed a bug where helical gears would create bad objects.

description.text:
Hommage à Fermat, qui écrivit « Au contraire, il est impossible de partager soit un cube en deux cubes, soit un bicarré en deux bicarrés, soit en général une puissance quelconque supérieure au carré en deux puissances de même degré : j'en ai découvert une démonstration véritablement merveilleuse que cette marge est trop étroite pour contenir. »

In memory of Fermat who write that no three positive integers a, b, and c can satisfy the equation an + bn = cn for any integer value of n greater than two.

title: Live Life to the Fullest Tag ( In Remembrance of 2 of my friend's death this week)

description.text:
Remember that our lives can be cut short, that's what happened to two of my friends.

One was on his way to become a doctor.
The other was becoming an engineer.

Both were really talented and very kind people, but sadly they both died at the age of 22 due to accidents in which they couldn't avoid.

Here is "InMoov", the robot you can print and animate. You have a 3D printer, some building skills, This project is for you!! Remember this, all these parts are under a non-commercial license, see the terms. These are the ears which can be added to the head. inmoov.blogspot.com A bit of history videos:
youtube.com/watch?v=JztSQpwZaRU youtube.com/watch?v=zvbNcuUPHyQ youtube.com/watch?v=BAs2F4sFVdA Last of all:
http://youtu.be/W62Wfz1xqYg

Print all parts. Mine are done with ABS.
I already expect some remarks about these "Too" human ears...
But the head of InMoov looked flat when seen from the front, and adding human ears, helps in that matter. You can follow the assembly tutorial.
http://inmoov.blogspot.fr/p/assembly-help.html Update 28/02/14 I added new ears that allow setting speakers in the head. There is no specification given for to buy the speakers. Standard small USB speakers for PC should be fine. You can use the STL Speaker1 to know the dimensions required.
Here is a link to speakers that fit:
http://www.madisoundspeakerstore.com/approx-2-fullrange/peerless-830970-2-full-range-4-ohm/

title: HP Network and Spectrum Analyzer Accessory Power Plug

description.text: HP RF test equipment uses a small 3 pin connector to provide power to external probes and accessories. HP doesn't provide these easily and they are not a standard Digi-Key type of buy. If you want to make accessories for HP Network or Spectrum Analyzers- custom probes, pre-amps, fixtures, etc- Its nice to be be able to power them from this internal power source rather than a power brick or batteries. This is a simple design that I've used with several cables and gadgets- I generally use a 7805 and 7905 regulator in my designs to regulate the power down to +-5V. The connector body has the correct geometry to line up with the pins of the HP female connector. IC socket pins, discarded DB-25 pins, etc can be soldered and friction fit in the hole. Some scrounging required. A groove that will enhance the grip of heat shrink at the transition from the cable to the connector is provided. Comments welcome.

description.text: A pipboy 3000 that fits a Samsung Galaxy S5 with a slot for a 9v battery should anyone decide to add electronics to the lights and such.

So after some modification, this pipboy 3000 now fits the Samsung Galaxy S5, and is set up to run on a Z18 (It will take roughly 25-40 hours at medium settings). After cleanup, I will sand the plastic smooth and apply a layer of primer paints before applying model paints to make it look like in the game. The hinge will actually snap in place once printed and need only a 1/8" or smaller metal rod to hinge. This can be 3D printed plastic or be metal. Screw holes are included to screw everything in place, and a couple extra screw holes for aesthetics. More to come, including some tweaks to the 3d model after some flaws I noticed.

EDIT: People have been asking, the height of the tallest piece is about 8.03125 (or 8 1/32) Inches, or about 20.5 CM. If your software messes with the scale of the print scale accordingly to get that overall height. Also, the screw holes are there for aesthetic reasons for the most part, but to screw it together I just used some black screws from recent computer builds. Here's a link: http://amzn.to/1LWi0Rn

These pillow blocks wrap the RapMan X and Y axis bearings in a nice comfy pillow instead of pinching them between bolts and acrylic sheets. Why would you want to do this?
  • Bearings run smoother when not pinched.
  • It greatly reduces the RapMan's rain of falling nuts and washers.
  • You can tighten these down with only a single hex wrench.
  • You wont easily snap the acrylic parts when you tighten them.
  • They are more stable.
  • They look cool.
    • These are similar to the pillow blocks that can be found here: http://wiki.bitsfrombytes.com/index.php?title=Spare_parts but are a new design with several features the others don't have:
  • These pillow blocks are not closed and can be installed with out taking the bearings off the rail so they require much less disassembly.
  • There is a backstop inside which makes centering the bearing easy.
  • There are insets for the bottom nuts which both keeps them from spinning out and makes them easier to tighten.
  • These don't change the height of the extruder or x-axis.
  • They come with a cool bearing packing tool.
    • These were designed to be easy to print and to fit the nuances of the RapMan. If you want a general purpose pillow block then the front x-axis block is a good place to start. All of the STL files were generated from the OpenSCAD and .dxf files. The .dxf was created with QCad. I also highly recommend replacing the z-axis drive gear with the one at the bottom of this page: http://wiki.bitsfrombytes.com/index.php?title=Spare_parts and replacing your extruder gears with these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4650 I haven't gotten these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4398 to print cleanly yet but they look interesting too. With these pillow blocks and the replacement gears my RapMan is starting to become a reliable and smooth running printing machine. Maybe they should call it the StRapMan.

Print one of each of the parts, except for the x-axis front pillow block which you print two of.  You can print a whole set at once if you like.  The whole x-axis must be done all at once.
Optionally print the bearing packing/depacking tool which helps push the bearings in and out of the blocks with out damaging them.
Clean the parts of any burs or strings, especially from the inside of the block.  I used a file with a rounded side.  Also make sure an M5 bolt will pass through each of the holes.  Pushing one back and forth a few times helps to clear out the holes.
Remove the extruder and disassemble the x-axis carriage.  Keep all the nuts and bolts but the bottom plate will no longer be needed.
Install the three pillow blocks by popping them over the bar and pushing the bearing inside.  Make sure you orient the block the right way and that you have the right one before you pop it on.  The bearings can only go into the pillow block from one side.  Insert the nuts with out the washers in to the bottom and screw in the bolts from the top.  If things don't line up you probably have the wrong block or have it the wrong way on the bar.  If the bearing wont go in make sure you are inserting it from the correct side of the block.
Take the 14 washers and put 7 on the bottom of each of the belt bolts.  Put a nut on each bolt and tighten the stack.  The seven washers should be just thick enough to get the bolt on tight.  Then put the belt loops back on the bolts.  This should be ridged even without the bottom plate.
Now disassemble the y-axis, install the pillow blocks and reassemble one side at a time.  Each pillow block has its place.  You do not have to disconnect the y-axis bars from the corners.  You no longer need the 4 small bottom plates.
Push the y-axis wire tube in to its new clip and reinstall the extruder.
Make sure your machine is still aligned.  The z-axis may have moved by a small amount (< 1mm) relative to the extruder.
Take a picture and click the 'I made one!' button.

description.text:
A platform designed to help you understand how changes in mass affect the center of gravity and buoyancy of an object. Detachable cups also allow mass to be added on various sides of the boat, as well as act as floats.

After you're done with your experimentation, print out some mounts and turn your boat into a tri-copter!

Update 5: Yet another version! This time of the Hexapod core, with a flat base (for those with puny printers, or a low tolerance for waiting around like me)

Update 4: Added another version of the arms, this time with a rectangular extension away from the main HexaFloat core.

Update 3: Added a version of the arms that doesn't have an extension away from the main HexaFloat core.

Update 2: Added mounting holes for HexaFloat arms.

Update: Revision fixed scaling issues in design. Scaled up from original by 700% (old version couldn't even hold a penny D:)

Printed with 20% infill and two shells. If your print starts to take on water through layers, increase the number of shells. This object is spiral-vase printable. Just make sure that you lower print speeds to allow for better layer adhesion and durability.

Printed arms with 30% infill and two shells. If the prints start to take on water through layers, increase the number of shells. Supports may be needed for the pegs to print properly, and a properly calibrated and leveled printer will be able to handle tolerances better.

remixed_from.author: tosjduenfs
remixed_from.title: Mini Flame Wheel Style Quadcopter frame.

title: 250mm flame wheel based quad (V2 now public)

description.text:
I took thing 34552 and went crazy modifying it for my specific hardware.

UPDATE 06/27/15
Added source for XT60 mount.
Maiden flight went well. Does not feel too heavy or underpowered. Found a weak spot in the arm design.

UPDATE 06/30/15
I think I have my final arm design. Still breaks under high impact to protect motors but seems to be strong enough.
Added optional 808 camera mount. It MUST be printed with support. (still working on finalizing the design)
Updated design to version 2.

UPDATE 06/30/15
Version 2 is a public release. Make sure you read the instructions before starting to print. I included my beta 808 camera mount. This part is not mentioned in the instructions.

UPDATE 07/02/15
Some files were not fully manifold. Issue should be resolved. Added Hobbyking.com product IDs to hardware list in instructions.

UPDATE 07/13/15

I've moved onto another quad design and decided to release the sketchup source and allow people to branch off of my design. License has been changed to reflect this.

These instructions assume you have at least a hobbyist experience level building RC models. If you get stuck at any point, YouTube is your friend! I wrote this up in one go so there may be errors. The images provided were taken during testing and may not represent the current version.

I recommend printing the front and rear arms in different colors for better visual orientation. Print extra arms in both colors, you will probably need them.

I printed the entire thing in PLA because that is what I use. If you print in ABS or some other material, please share your experience with assembly and durability!

PLA print settings:
0.4mm nozzle
0.2 layer height
4 top/bottom layers
2 shells
25% infill
110% extrusion for high layer bonding

Hardware: (Hobbyking.com product IDs)
Hobbyking KK2.1 flight controller (HK# 9171000446-0 )
9X8Cv2 receiver (HK# RX-9X8Cv2)
(4) Turnigy 1811 brushless outrunner 2900kv (HK# T1811-2900)
(4) Turnigy Plush 6a Speed controllers (HK# TR-6A)
5030 black propellers (cw + ccw) (HK# 9332000002)
5030 red propellers (cw + ccw) (HK# 9332000003)
Turnigy nano-tech 1500mah 2S Lipo pack (HK# 9210000075)
Male XT60 connector (HK# 601Ax5)
(3) Male to Male servo extension lead (HK# 258000154-0)
(18) M3 8mm bolts
(2) M3 10mm bolts
(4) M3 16mm bolts

Supplies:
Scotch 1in wide 10lb indoor foam mounting tape
4in zip ties
3M dual lock Velcro strips
5/64ths drill bit and drill
Time

Assembly:
1) Clean with 91% rubbing alcohol and install 3M Dual Lock strip to inner side of vertical wall on bottom plate.
2) Mount battery top to bottom plate using (4) M3 8mm bolts
3) Mount (4) arms to (4) holes in bottom plate (talon down) using (4) M3 8mm bolts
4) Trim speed controller out leads to ~13mm and solder on female bullet connectors included with 1811 motors. Insulate with included shrink tubing.
5) Snap speed controllers into mounts on bottom side of arms label up and out leads towards talons. Run servo lead and ground to one side of post and the positive to the other.
6) Strip and twist all red speed controller wires together and solder to positive side of XT60 male connector. Repeat for black wires to negative side. If using voltage input for KK2.1 board, include the leads for the plug.
7) Run power wires and servo wires through center slot in top plate and mount top plate to arms through the outer most holes using (4) M3 16mm bolts. Make sure wires do not get pinched between arms and top plate.
8) Cleanup and shape lower XT60 mount until it snaps into upper XT60 mount. Remove support material from recessed holes on upper XT60 mount. Make sure you are lining up the inner step on both halves.
9) Once the halves of the XT60 mount snap together, insert XT60 connector into the halves and trim the rectangle protrusions until the mount snugly clamps down on the connector.
10) Slide XT60 mount into slot on top plate and mount with (2) M3 10mm bolts through the top plate and into the arms.
11) Instal (6) M3 8mm bolts through top plate and into remaining arm holes. Tuck power leads and the voltage input if you are using it into the center slot in the top plate and run the servo leads up through center slot and opposite the XT60 connector.
12) Run the antenna up through the antenna mount on the top plate. Run the KK2.1 buzzer wire down through it's mount and through the center slot in the top plate. Push buzzer into mount.
13) With the XT60 connector to the left and top plate up, mount the receiver to the furthest protrusion on the lower plate with 1" mounting tape. (the end with the wall you installed the Dual Lock to) Make sure you leave room between the arms and receiver for the speed controller leads.
14) Making sure you do not pinch the servo leads, mount KK2.1 board to the standoffs on the top plate using (4) M3 8mm bolts. The front of the KK2.1 board should be facing the receiver.
14) Run servo extension leads from receiver to KK2.1 board. Zip tie to KK2.1 standoff. Plug in servo leads from speed controllers to KK2.1 board. Plug in the buzzer and voltage input leads into the KK2.1 if you are using it.
15) Solder male bullet connectors onto leads on motors. insulate with shrink tubing. Drill out center of propellers using a 5/64ths drill bit.
16) Instal mounting tape to motor mounts on arms and drill out mounting holes with 5/64ths drill bit. Run motor leads through rectangle hole in arms and mount motors to mounting tape lining up the holes you drilled. You can run zip ties through holes to mount the motors more securely but I would not do that until you get good at not crashing as the motors will no longer break free on impact.
17) Connect motor leads to speed controllers and verify rotation is correct. Zip tie speed controller leads through arm holes. Instal propellers and program KK2.1 board.

Happy flying!

description.text:
New support for Z-axis printer 3DRag / k8200.
Replaces the original and eliminates 90% of the effect "Wobble Z", with the help of flexible coupling.

Nuovo supporto per asse Z della stampante 3DRag/k8200.
Sostituisce quello originale ed elimina del 90% l'effetto "Z Wobble", con l'aiuto del giunto elastico.

Bill of Materials - BOM:

  • 1 part1
  • 1 part2
  • 2 Screws M5x35
  • 1 nut M8
  • 3 screws M3X40
  • 3 nuts M3
  • 3 springs

Distinta materiali:

  • 1 parte1
  • 1 parte 2
  • 2 Viti M5X35
  • 1 Dato M8
  • 3 Viti M3X40
  • 3 Dadi M3
  • 3 Molle

This is not completely hashed out, and is slightly smaller than a standard Mendel. But it should allow a frame to be constructed from these vertex modules. I've made special vertices for the top of the frame for the X motor and idler as the carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9385 can now slide along the top bars. The Y axis components (still being worked on but in the SCAD file) slide on the lower two bars, so mechanical requirements are simple. The sockets are parametric and will work with screws, bolts, glue or - my personal favourite - tape and a mallet. With a bit of luck, the ARNIE string Z axis revival will allow a RepRap to be made without any threaded or steel rod in it at all.

Push 9mm extruded aluminium tubing into the sockets and join them together to make a Mendel frame. They should be quite sturdy, but one can always add superglue, self-tappers or epoxy when one is sure of the alignment.

title: Quanum Toxic Nitro reinforced Bull Bar

description.text:

This little thing believed to be a bioluminescent mushroom, "foxfire" or "glow wood".

Arduino controled:
use 60 mm of pileus diameter to housing one color std 5 mm led, for RGB use 90 mm (scale 1.5 or 150%). Use white or translucent filament.
Control the RGB led, Arduino code added: LED_Rainbow.ino

Caution this model is very dangerous for children under 8 years, see intructions

News
7/20/2015 - arduino control for RGB led mushroom florest or single, vide on mushroom video for LED_Rainbow.ino Arduino program

see:
Mycena chlorophos
"Mycena chlorophos is a species of agaric fungus in the family Mycenaceae. First described in 1860, the fungus is found in subtropical Asia, including Japan, Taiwan, Polynesia, Java, and Sri Lanka, in Australia, and Brazil." (extracted from wikipedia)

This little thing believed to be a bioluminescent mushroom

Arduino controled:

Control the RGB led, Arduino code added: LED_Rainbow.ino and the circuit diagrams on pictures gallery.

Caution this utility model is very dangerous for children, see below

description.text: this is a modified version of the T-Rex skull base, it is adapted to let you put some leds in the base to iluminate the skull

i cut the rod about in half and cut a notch out of it, then i fed the led leads thru the rod and out the side of it. this can be more easily understood with the included picture of the finished model.
Printcraft Logo

This is a portable and adjustable-height vise for PCB assembly and rework.

It is inspired by Hakko Omnivise C1390C.

Required hardware:

  • M8 hex bolt >= 20mm x1
  • M8 nut x1
  • M3 hex screw, countersink, 6 to 10 mm x6
  • M3 hex screw, socket cap, >=6 mm x3
  • M3 nut x9

Print 2 copy of the jaw, and one copy of everything else. The stencil is optional.

I printed with PLA with 0.2 mm layer and 20% infill.

The body part is tricky because it has a lot of helical cuts inside. On my delta printer it printed better with support, although removing the support is PITA.

A thin layer of RTV silicone can be applied on the jaw for better grip. Make sure you cover the screws so they don't scratch the PCB. I tried to use the stencil to make a pattern but it didn't turn out very well (bad seal between the stencil and jaw. maybe printing on glass bed will help). Also apply RTV silicone onto the bottom. It makes grippy rubber feet.

In the bottom part, fill in some heavy stuff to help balance the vise. Aluminum capacitors are not dense enough. Maybe some solder will work better.

title: VW Automatic Window Regulator Clip Both Side Improved

description.text:
This is based on the work of chuck : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11954
I remove some useless material to make is lighter, and mirrored it to have the driver's side. I made two versions, see below why.
Perfectly fits my Volkswagen POLO 6N1 1996
The freecad files are included, so feel free to improve it !

Please print it with the highest filling setting if possible (use files named XXX_Improved.stl or freecad project improved_model2).
If you cannot (or do not want to) print the part full you may prefer the reinforced parts with name ending with "holes". When printing in "medium" filling setting, this will create reinforcement points where the part needs it (else, it will break ...).
The original stl from chuck was imported in FreeCad (Linux), and reworked. Then I printed it using PLA on my M3D printer (it tooks 4 hours).

comments.text:
Mine lasted 2 weeks before I replaced them with chinese copies (that took two weeks to come to france ...).
When I remove them, they were a little bit damaged / bent, so I don't think they would have last more time.
I printed them using PLA but I would have better use ABS to print them, because here (in south of France), PLA pieces can bent due to the summer heat (can be 40°C).

author: DENOVATOR

description.text:
This alignment system is for the use with a 200 x 200 mm² heatbed. It faciliates the operator to manipulate the height of the heatbed from the bottom side of the heatbed. An Allen key access hole is on the bottom side of the plate-clamps.
The design is made for use of m4 DIN912 screws for height alignment and the frame rods and M3 DIN912 screws for holding the heatbed as well as the clamp fixation on the ground plate.
Do not forget to get some springs fitting in the endholders for the heatbed.
The height adjustion needs some groove-nuts. I designed the endcaps for the use with the cheap groove nuts for aluminium profiles of type B. M4 Nuts as I've stated above.

Have fun printing and enjoy the easy way of height adjustion.

If you have comments or worthy tips please let me know.

Cheers C.

Getting the springs inserted and mound the endcaps onto the heatbed might be a little tricky. Maybe you can apply a little scotchtape and push the heatbed between the spring and the upper stop. Afterwards you can pull the scothtape out and mount the screw.

When printing with support structure (recommended) think of cleaning the groove for inserting the m4 bolt easily. Do not clean to much otherwhise the screw head is not clamped rigildly enough inside the groove.

title: Star Wars Blaster with Light Saber Baenet

description.text: This is a simple cosplay where you have a classic DC 17 blaster pistol know fitted with a Light Saber baenet. This baenet is detachable depending on the job, convention or clone trooper brandishing the weapon. The baenet also has an actual rod that comes out of the saber for an authentic look.

First print out the blaster it'll give you something to play with a you wait. Then print out the baenet saber make sure you can screw in the bottom piece. Then slide on the baenet. Commence with printing out the rod pieces. Take off the baenet and unscrew the bottom. place in the rod pieces in Russian Doll Style (place in the biggest on then the medium then the smallest. Finally go to a mirror and pose to see how cool you look.
For optimum bossness get an led and print in a translucent color then place the led in a small circuit with a switch and a battery ( connect led+ to switch -, then switch+ to battery -, and finally battery+ to led -). Use a knife or Dremel to cut a hole big enough for your switch. Insert your switch and keep it in place with hot glue. The rest of your circuit should be inside hot glue your circuit to the bottom. Note that if you do this it will wont open without damage to your circuit. Again go to a mirror and pose to see how cool you look.

Here's a group I made for my LED lights and things, if you like my LED designs, join the group and you'll be updated as I upload new ones... I plan on making a lot more logos just like this. So if you have and suggestions, please tell me and I'll make it.

http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/things-with-leds/things

This is a extruded LED Maker Faire Robot I printed on my dual extruder... I took a JPEG of the Make logo and traced it in Solidworks... I then extruded and filleted the robot and saved it as its own STL to be used in dual extrusion... I then designed a plate around therobot, added holes for screws and save that as its own STL... Lastly, I design a shell to go around the plate and robot, the shell has aligned screw holes so it can be fastened to the plate...

I then printed the shell in regular ole black PLA on my Rep 2... And I did the dual extrusion using the same black PLA for the plate and I used Bendlay (link below) to print the robot... I used Bendlay because it is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)...

I then hooked up an RGB LED strip, wrapped it around the inner shell and hooked it up to an IR receiver so it can be controlled with a remote...

I've also made the following logo's, designs for LED hookup...

Hi,
yet another spool holder. This one is mounted directly to the frame of my Sparkcube 3D Printer. If you have a simmilar frame design (using cubic mounted 20x20 type B Aluminium profiles) you can use this spoolholder as well.
The fixation is done using M4 DIN912 screews and the fitting groove nuts. The appropriate spaces left for inserting the nuts is only for the use with cheap M4 groove nuts.
The bearing used is a radial ball bearing with a diameter of 19 mm.
If you need more information or have feedback please let me know.

Have fun printing!

Cheers! C.

Here's a video of it in action... The heart has it's own LED controller that continuously beats red. While the letters are controlled by the remote...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L1L_YluT1x8

Here's a group I made for my LED lights and things, if you like my LED designs, join the group and you'll be updated as I upload new ones... I plan on making a lot more logos just like this. So if you have and suggestions, please tell me and I'll make it.

http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/things-with-leds/things

This is a extruded LED I <3 3D Printing sign/nightlight I printed on my dual extruder... I modeled it in Solidworks by importing a text that I liked from a screenshot... I then extruded and filleted the heart and letter and saved it as its own STL to be used in dual extrusion... I then designed a plate around the heart and letter, added holes for screws and saved that as its own STL... Lastly, I designed a shell to go around the plate and robot, the shell has aligned screw holes so it can be fastened to the plate...

I then printed the shell in regular ole black PLA on my Rep 2... And I did the dual extrusion using the same black PLA for the plate and I used Bendlay (link below) to print the robot... I used Bendlay because it is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)...

I then hooked up an RGB LED strip, wrapped it around the inner shell and hooked it up to an IR receiver so it can be controlled with a remote...

I've also made the following logo's, designs for LED hookup...

title: Operating panel and electronics holder (Ramps 1.4) with fan mounting system

description.text:
Hi,

this design is used to mount the electronics used for my Sparkcube 3D printer.
The design is aimed for mounting on a cubic aluminium frame using 20x20 mm² type B aluminium profiles. I think the mounting instructions are self-explanatory.
I'm using M4 DIN912 screws for mounting. The heads fit well into the cuts.
On the fotos you see that there are additional holes, this is due to my first design error (backside-clamp to much into the middle). This error is already corrected.

If you have questions or suggestions please leave me a massage.
Have fun printing.

Cheers! C.

A socket for mounting LED's into standard perforated 1/4" hole pegboard.

Print the sockets and clips in batches. I found that a batch of eight printed on a raft yielded good results. The socket will work with two lead 3mm, 5mm and 8mm LED's. The LED leads will have to be trimmed to make an electrical connection with both pins. The socket portion of the clip is a standard, low cost female machined round header. Simply snap off a section of two and use a thick cyanoacrylate to glue them on. It is best to use a trimmed LED to position the header section when glueing. Also while glueing, try to place the socket in a position/orientation where the glue will not wick into the lead holes.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5OHlLZ5ZRYc

comments.text:
Being the nerd that I am, I noticed that you have a slightly incorrect value for Pi in the source code.
Being the engineer I am, I understand the difference between accuracy and precision - and know that it won't really matter.
However, being the perfectionist that I am, I just had to mention it and hope that you will correct it.
You're missing a 3 in the 27th decimal position just after the 8.
:)
comments.author: DrBoo

comments.text:
That was actually intentional to compensate for scaling issues in the xy inherent in my 3d printer at the time. It took me a lot of work to figure out just the right Pi to use, it was a complete fluke that the last 4 digits happen to match.
:-P
comments.author: DrBoo

comments.text: "How many digits of pi would we need to calculate the circumference of a circle with a radius of 46 billion light years to an accuracy equal to the diameter of a hydrogen atom (the simplest atom)? The answer is that you would need 39 or 40 decimal places."   So when you're talking about changing the 27th digit, I find it really hard to believe that makes a difference to your X/Y scaling.  10^-27 is an astronomically small number.

title: Supporto per finecorsa / Support for endstop [SainSmart]

description.text:
I tradizionali supporti per finecorsa che ho trovato su internet non sono fatti bene o almeno non sono compatibili con i miei finecorsa della SainSmart. Ho deciso di ridisegnare i supporti per i finecorsa che avevo trovato e renderli conpatibili con i miei come vedete ho spostato i fori verso lesterno e ho tagliato l'asta d 3mm per non farla scontrare con le saldature e in fine ho anche allargato leggermente il foro del dato per farlo entrare senza problemi.

The traditional supports to endstop that I found on the internet are not made well or at least are not compatible with my endstop of SainSmart. I decided to reshape the media that I had found the endstop and make them compatible with my, as you see I have moved the holes out and I cut the rod of 3mm to keep it to collide with the welds and in the end I also widened slightly hole as to make it fit without problems.

title: Camera plate for 20x60 V-Slot extruded aluminum

description.text:
Creating a timelapse slider. Need two camera mounts to attach tripods at each end.

This is a camera mount that is both a quick release and a standard 1/4"-20 thread.

While I was at it I also created mounts for 20X40 and 20X20 V-slots

Parts from here: http://openbuildspartstore.com/
4 - T-Nuts
4 - M5 10mm bolts
1 - 1/4"-20 T-nuts for camera mount

To get the Camera mount nut to mount flush in place I had to heat it up with a lighter. I first pushed it in as far as I could then heated it and use a bolt on the other side to pull it into place. The flame passed up through the hole but the it heated up enough to melt the plastic just enough to get it into place and never move.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online

description.text:
This is a 4pc. spool holder that I designed for the Robo 3D R1 Printer. This is my first actual design so tolerances might be a bit tight, but nothing a light sanding wont fix. All together it is a nice holder for 1 spool that is 8"Dia. x 2.5"H (Standard 1KG Spool). A large improvement over the flimsy holder it comes with.

The print took approx. 3 hours in total on low settings. The quality is incredible though and the parts are very stiff and strong.

(See Instructions for Installation)

This assembly was made in solid works and I have attached the assembly just in case someone wants to modify it. Some light sanding of parts might be required (the leg tips as seen in the picture) but overall once printed little to no modification is needed. The legs are meant to fit tight against the notch on top so just rotate until it pops into place (the print and printer should handle the stress otherwise simply sand a bit). Once attached slide in the spacer and then attach the rod w/ your spool on top.

The replicator 2 and 2X have issues with its Z axis having play, movement and stickiness which causes uneven print layers. You will notice this by jogging the Z axis up about 3/4 of the way. If you push up on the build plate from the bottom and pull down on it you will notice the play. Although that play is very minimal, it dramatically effects your print layers. The stickiness in the Z axis occurs because of the bushings.If the Z axis used linear bearings instead of bushings this would not occur.

The Ballast was designed to hold extra weight on the build plate to force the Z axis to drop down each layer as the screw rod lowers. By adding weight to your build plate, this will eliminate inconsistent layers while printing.

I used loose coins in my ballast for weight. You can place coins or steel ball bearings in yours. DO NOT PLACE SAND OR WATER IN YOUR BALLAST.

  1. Take your back plate out that sits on your build platform. The back plate has the red Makerbot logo on it which covers your threaded rod and has 2 screws to hold it in place.

  2. Once the back plate is removed, insert the printed ballast in the cavity that the back plate covered.

  3. The printed ballast has a groove in it to prevent the threaded rod from being touched. Make sure your printed ballast groove goes in first around that threaded rod.

  4. Now reinstall the back plate and screw the 2 screws back in place securing the printed ballast.

  5. Jog the build platform up about 3/4 the way on the Z axis.

  6. Fill the printed ballast up with your desired material. Either use loose coins or steel ball bearings by adding a little at a time. Make sure you place the same amount of weight equally on both sides of your ballast for even weight distribution.

  7. Check the build plate by pushing it up from the bottom and letting it go. If the build plate does NOT drop down on its own, then add more weight until it drops down when you lift up. Do not fill the ballast all the way up WITHOUT CHECKING THE WEIGHT IN SMALL INCREMENTS. It may be too much weight and may cause damage to your Z axis stepper motor.

  8. Once you have found the desired weight, its time to level the build plate again. DO NOT SKIP THIS STEP, VERY IMPORTANT FOR ACCURATE PRINTS.

  9. Do a test print, if your prints horizontal lines are all even and consistent, your Z axis is dialed in.

1. Take your back plate out that sits on your build platform. The back plate has the red Makerbot logo on it which covers your threaded rod and has 2 screws to hold it in place.

  2. Once the back plate is removed, insert the printed ballast in the cavity that the back plate covered.

  3. The printed ballast has a groove in it to prevent the threaded rod from being touched. Make sure your printed ballast groove goes in first around that threaded rod.

  4. Now reinstall the back plate and screw the 2 screws back in place securing the printed ballast.

  5. Jog the build platform up about 3/4 the way on the Z axis.

  6. Fill the printed ballast up with your desired material. Either use loose coins or steel ball bearings by adding a little at a time. Make sure you place the same amount of weight equally on both sides of your ballast for even weight distribution.

  7. Check the build plate by pushing it up from the bottom and letting it go. If the build plate does NOT drop down on its own, then add more weight until it drops down when you lift up. Do not fill the ballast all the way up WITHOUT CHECKING THE WEIGHT IN SMALL INCREMENTS. It may be too much weight and may cause damage to your Z axis stepper motor.

  8. Once you have found the desired weight, its time to level the build plate again. DO NOT SKIP THIS STEP, VERY IMPORTANT FOR ACCURATE PRINTS.

  9. Do a test print, if your prints horizontal lines are all even and consistent, your Z axis is dialed in.

I've been looking into some enclosures for my Afinia H480. Either they are way too expensive, have a huge materials list, or are just over complicated.

My solution, which works great by the way, was just to use a 27gal tub, with large enough inner dimensions to fully enclose my H480. I crudely cut out a small hole in the side, added two 0.79 hinges, two 0.59 magnetic door stops, and a 1.00 door handle. The tub and parts were found at my local Home Depot, and in total cost about $10.

I have a slight overhang over the edge of the desk, and obviously the door isn't air tight, but it keeps the temp very stable and my warping/heat bed issues have gone by the wayside.

This printer is on my office desk, and has an AC vent almost directly above it. I did not want to move the printer to another room in the house, so I improvised, and now my print quality has drastically improved.

I know it's crude, and most items on here are generally made by our printers, but I wanted to offer someone, who is experiencing the same issues I had, a very cheap alternative to a normally much more expensive solution.

comments.text: Great idea - but why didn't you just print the hinges and the knob?  You could have even printed the screws and nuts, or made pins to hold the hinges.  It takes awhile to get to thinking "I can print that!",  but once you do you will reduce your trips to the hardware store, and save a ton of cash in a year's time.

title: Lantern builder set - combine it as you like

description.text:
here you find a building set for lanterns. You need no glue and you can change the parts as often as you like. Put the parts together an turn - ready. See the picture how to combine the parts. The lanterns designed for electric tea lights. You could fix the tea light with a rubber ring to switch the tea light on and off by turning the lantern. (it depends on the type of tea light you use). Attention - Do not use normal tea lights at the lantern! https://youtu.be/PFE54GnNC-Y
Information: i printed with 0.1mm, but the printing quality of my printer is poor, so i am sure you will have better results.
Special version is the solar light - see instructions for more information

My intention was to make small LED project that everyone could understand and build. Most of the commercial solar lanterns have no accu capacity indicator. So the idea is to use the led with different colors to show the accu capacity. (red=low, green=normal, blue=full) To make the project more advanced i use an easy to programm and cheap micrcontroller. (more informations www.picaxe.com) I use this once if the project is to small for an arduino. You find the circuit, the programm and a build description at my pictures above.
The advantage of a microcontroller is that you could expand the project. I use it for instance with a bluetooth modul and a temperature and soil humidity sensor. All theese datas i receive with my smartphone. Or you use a motion sensor and a small horn to prevent you garden from animals at night. But i am sure you will have more ideas.

As soon as I installed jasonatepaint's Rostock LED light ring, I was in love with this idea. I used the 1 watt LEDs and resistor he suggested and it was great. But the LEDs were so bright that I saw spots. I made little light shields for them using tape.  
Here I have copied his design, making most of it a little thinner and adding light shields around the LEDs so they don't blind me anymore. It's like recessed lighting for the LEDs.  
2014-06-07: Included another stl without all the backing. A bit simpler than the original since everything goes in from the back, no support, no tape. I've been using this for about 9 months and I prefer it over the other one.

I printed with support. It only took 5 min to clean out the few spots where it added support where the track for the wire causes overhangs.  
I wired three 1 watt LEDs in series with a 33 ohm 1/4 watt resistor on the positive side to a switch and the 12v power supply of my rostock max. I just copied jasonatepaint's instructions. You could maybe add a pot to adjust brightness, but with the shielding, brightness isn't so blinding.  
After you install the LEDs on the ring, you can tape off the two slits in each light shield. Without the slits, I don't think the LEDs would fit in there. The light shields also have a small hole pointing toward the nozzle. You can try leaving that open or tape it off if you don't like it.  
The light ring has mounting holes to match the effector plate on the rostock max and the shields are short enough for the newer seemecnc flatter nozzle.

description.text:
A PCO 28 compatible PET bottle cap for pneumatic fittings.

Supported Fittings/Holes:

  • 1 x 5mm
  • 2 x 5mm
  • 2 x 5mm, wide
  • 1 x 6mm
  • bare; drill your own holes

I recommend printing the cap at 0.1mm layer height, with at least 50% infill.

If you don't have a suitable gasket, you can cut your own with the provided gasket cutting tool.
Just print two "GasketTool.stl", put a piece of rubber in between (after poking/cutting a hole in it), fix all with a 3mm screw/nut and carefully cut it down to size.
Protip: Old bicycle tubes will also work fine ;-)

Depending on the fittings and the gasket, it might be required to additionally apply some teflon tape (thread seal tape) to the threads of the fittings and the bottle.
A rotating gasket can be fixed with a drop of glue.

Distance of the cap's mounting holes is 40mm.

description.text:
Disclaimer: I am not a Canadian. Had a couple coins left from a trip to Canada and my wife liked the beaver on the nickel so I tried to make a necklace. I am not sure how these will print on an FDM machine, I printed on an SLA machine in clear resin. The maple leaf on the back of the nickel charm was taken from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567539.
Note, the uploaded penny version is slightly different from the one pictured--the hole needed to be enlarged to make it big enough to thread on a necklace chain.

description.text: I took the .ai files from 4volt and imported them into inkscape. The paths for the parts weren't closed after the import, resulting in each line being cut separately. I closed them in the .svg file and added layers and colors to allow selective cutting of the pieces. Thanks to 4volt for a nice design!

-This is a coin raft that I modeled with the "Make it Float" Challenge in mind. I have printed a smaller version (About 2 inches by 2 inches) of the raft, which supports the weight of 4 quarters and 2 pennies. Bigger versions are able to be printed. Large half-cyllindars help keep the boat afloat! The top of the raft is flat for easy printing.

-I plan on making improvements/new versions of the coin raft in the next few days. Work in progress!

-Recommended 0% infill
